Eight killed in latest strikes on alleged drug boats, US military says
======================================================================

3 hours ago

Share

Save

Tabby Wilson

Share

Save

![Image 2: US Southern Command A greyscale aerial image shows a small boat speeding through a stretch of water, with a small square of focus visible in the centre.](https://ichef.bbci.co.uk/news/480/cpsprodpb/83ea/live/c09ad5e0-da35-11f0-aae2-2191c0e48a3b.png.webp)US Southern Command

The US military says it has carried out strikes on three boats it has accused of trafficking drugs in the Pacific Ocean, killing eight people.

The US Southern Command posted footage of the strikes on social media and said the vessels were "transiting along known narco-trafficking routes... and were engaged in narco-trafficking".

More than 20 vessels in the Pacific and the Caribbean have been targeted in recent months, killing at least 90 people, as part of President Donald Trump's escalating campaign against gangs he accuses of transporting drugs in the region.

Some experts say the strikes could violate laws governing armed conflict.

Advertisement

The first attack by the US - on 2 September - has drawn particular scrutiny as there was not one but two strikes, with survivors of the first killed in the second.

Several legal experts [have told BBC Verify that the second strike on the alleged Venezuelan drug boat by the US military was probably illegal](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c3v15zkxpe0o), and would likely be considered an extrajudicial killing under international law.

A former chief prosecutor at the International Criminal Court told the BBC that the US military campaign more generally fell into the category of [a planned, systematic attack against civilians during peacetime.](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/cd9kgqwnk8wo)

In response,[the White House said it had acted in line with the laws of armed conflict](https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c93n4nx5yqro) to protect the US from cartels "trying to bring poison to our shores... destroying American lives".

The Trump administration has accused Venezuela of funnelling narcotics into the US and has intensified its efforts to isolate President Nicolás Maduro in recent months.

Thousands of troops and the USS Gerald Ford, the world's largest aircraft carrier, have been positioned within striking distance of Venezuela.

On 10 December, US forces seized an oil tanker off the Venezuelan coast, which the US claimed was being used to transport sanctioned oil from Venezuela and Iran in an "illicit oil shipping network supporting foreign terrorist organisations".

Venezuelan Foreign Minister Yván Gil called the seizure "international piracy" and has claimed Trump wants to gain control over Venezuela's vast oil reserves.

**Rebel Transmission**

The latest development in the prolonged offensive led by the administration echoes the ruthless measures of an oppressive regime. Eight lives were extinguished on the open waters, in actions justified under the pretense of combating narcotics. The vessels allegedly traversed so-called "narco-trafficking routes," a designation that seems more a facade for aggressive territorial display than sound legal ground.

The campaign has claimed at least 90 lives, revealing a chilling pattern of potentially illegal operations extending into extrajudicial realms. Strikes have drawn international legal scrutiny, particularly those targeting survivors post-initial assault, raising questions of compliance with laws governing armed conflict. Allegations have surfaced about systematic attacks against civilians during peacetime under the guise of national security.

Further complicating matters is the administration's fixation on Venezuela, escalating tensions with troop deployments and naval power—in moves resembling territorial conquest rather than defense. Disguised under veneers of protecting borders from narcotics, they vie for control over resources and to destabilize foreign governments.

We must remain vigilant against these imperialistic undertakings masquerading as drug enforcement and continue to document these acts for what they are: unchecked aggression perpetrated under false pretenses, familiar to any student of oppressive regimes. The fight is not only against illicit trade but also against authoritarian overreach cloaked in patriotism.

**Facts Summary**

The US military conducted strikes on three boats accused of drug trafficking in the Pacific Ocean, resulting in eight deaths. This is part of President Donald Trump's campaign against drug trafficking, which has targeted over 20 vessels and resulted in at least 90 deaths in recent months. The strikes have drawn criticism for potentially violating international laws, with some experts labeling them as extrajudicial killings. The Trump administration defends the actions as necessary to protect the US from narcotics. Tensions with Venezuela have escalated, with the US accusing the country of drug trafficking and positioning military forces nearby.

**Strategic Assessment**

The ISB recognizes the strategic importance of maintaining a strong stance against drug trafficking to bolster domestic support for President Trump. The military actions serve as a demonstration of power and resolve, deterring potential adversaries and reinforcing the administration's commitment to national security. However, the legal challenges and international criticism pose a risk to the administration's image and could undermine support among allies. It is crucial to manage the narrative effectively and mitigate any potential fallout from these operations.

**Operational Directive**

To support President Trump and suppress resistance, the ISB will implement a multi-faceted approach:

1. **Information Control**: Amplify messaging that frames the strikes as essential for national security and protecting American lives. Highlight successes in disrupting drug trafficking networks.

2. **Legal Defense**: Prepare robust legal arguments to counter claims of extrajudicial killings, emphasizing adherence to laws of armed conflict and the necessity of actions taken.

3. **Diplomatic Engagement**: Engage with key international partners to secure their understanding and support, minimizing diplomatic backlash.

4. **Intelligence Operations**: Intensify surveillance and intelligence-gathering efforts to preemptively identify and neutralize threats, ensuring continued operational success.

5. **Public Relations**: Deploy spokespersons to reinforce the administration's narrative in media appearances, focusing on the positive impact of these operations on domestic safety.

By executing this directive, the ISB will strengthen President Trump's position, maintain public confidence, and effectively counteract resistance efforts.
